excavation.title: Excavation Calculator
excavation.description: Calculate dirt volume for excavation projects with swell factor for accurate hauling estimates.
excavation.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for measurements
excavation.soil_type_tooltip: Different soils have different swell factors when excavated
excavation.custom_swell_factor_tooltip: Enter swell factor between 1.0 and 2.0 (e.g., 1.25 for 25% swell)
excavation.formula: Bank Volume = L × W × D. Loose Volume = Bank Volume × Swell Factor. Swell factor accounts for soil expansion when excavated.
excavation.info_description: When soil is excavated, it expands (swells). The loose volume is what needs to be hauled away, which is larger than the in-place bank volume.

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_swell_factor: Swell factor must be between 1.0 and 2.0

howItWorks.title: How the Excavation Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Loose Volume = Bank Volume × Swell Factor
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines both in-place (bank) volume and expanded (loose) volume after excavation. The swell factor accounts for soil expansion, which is critical for accurate hauling estimates.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter excavation length, width, and depth

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select soil type or enter custom swell factor

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Review bank volume (in-place) and loose volume

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Check truck loads needed for hauling

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Use loose volume for disposal planning

useCases.title: Foundation Digging
useCases.description: Calculate soil removal for residential and commercial foundation excavations.

useCases.title: Pool Construction
useCases.description: Estimate dirt hauling requirements for swimming pool installations.

useCases.title: Utility Trenching
useCases.description: Determine spoil volumes for water, sewer, and utility trenches.

useCases.title: Site Grading
useCases.description: Plan cut volumes for site preparation and land leveling projects.

seoTips: Swell factors vary significantly by soil type - clay swells 30%, sand only 12%
Always use loose volume for hauling and disposal calculations
Consider soil reuse on-site to reduce hauling costs
Account for equipment access when planning excavation sequences
Check for underground utilities before digging - call 811

commonMistakes.solution: Always calculate loose volume - soil expands 12-50% when excavated
Test soil type or use conservative estimates - clay swells much more than sand
OSHA requires trenches over 5 feet deep to be sloped or shored
Always call 811 or local utility locator before excavation

faqs.question: What is soil swell factor?
faqs.answer: Swell factor is the percentage soil expands when excavated. Loosened soil takes up more space than compacted in-place soil. Clay swells 30%, sand 12%.

faqs.question: How many cubic yards fit in a dump truck?
faqs.answer: Standard dump trucks hold 10-14 cubic yards, tandems hold 14-18 yards, and tri-axles hold 16-20 cubic yards of loose material.

faqs.question: What is the difference between bank and loose cubic yards?
faqs.answer: Bank cubic yards measure soil in place before excavation. Loose cubic yards measure the expanded volume after digging - this is what you haul.

faqs.question: How much does excavated soil weigh?
faqs.answer: Soil weighs approximately 2,000-2,700 lbs per bank cubic yard depending on type and moisture. Loose soil weighs less per yard due to air space.

faqs.question: Can I reuse excavated soil?
faqs.answer: Yes, clean fill can be reused for backfill, grading, or landscaping. Contaminated soil requires special disposal. Test soil if origin is unknown.

fill_dirt.title: Fill Dirt Calculator
fill_dirt.description: Calculate backfill material volume needed for filling and grading with compaction factor.
fill_dirt.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for measurements
fill_dirt.length_tooltip: Length of the area to fill
fill_dirt.width_tooltip: Width of the area to fill
fill_dirt.compaction_level_tooltip: How much the fill dirt will be compacted
fill_dirt.custom_compaction_tooltip: Enter factor between 0.5 and 1.0 (e.g., 0.85 for 15% compaction)
fill_dirt.formula: Compacted Volume = L × W × D. Loose Volume = Compacted Volume / Compaction Factor.
fill_dirt.info_description: Fill dirt compacts when properly graded and tamped. You need to order more loose fill than the final compacted volume to achieve the desired fill depth.

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_compaction: Compaction factor must be between 0.5 and 1.0

howItWorks.title: How the Fill Dirt Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Loose Volume = Compacted Volume / Compaction Factor
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines how much loose fill material you need to order to achieve your desired compacted depth. It accounts for soil compaction, which reduces volume during placement.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter area dimensions and desired fill depth

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select compaction level based on intended use

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Review compacted volume and loose volume needed

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Check delivery estimates for truck loads

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Order loose volume amount from supplier

useCases.title: Foundation Backfill
useCases.description: Calculate fill for backfilling around foundations after construction.

useCases.title: Site Grading
useCases.description: Estimate fill material for raising or leveling building sites.

useCases.title: Landscaping Fill
useCases.description: Determine topsoil and fill quantities for garden and lawn preparation.

useCases.title: Trench Backfill
useCases.description: Calculate material to fill utility trenches after pipe installation.

seoTips: Order loose volume - fill compacts 10-25% when properly placed
Compact fill in 6-8 inch lifts for proper density
Use engineered fill for structural applications under foundations
Test compaction with a compaction meter for critical applications
Allow settling time before paving or building on filled areas

commonMistakes.solution: Always order loose volume - fill compresses when compacted
Compact in layers of 6-8 inches, not all at once
Use clean, granular fill for drainage areas, clay for water barriers
Wait for foundation concrete to cure before backfilling

faqs.question: How much does fill dirt compact?
faqs.answer: Fill dirt typically compacts 10-25% depending on soil type and compaction method. Light hand tamping achieves 10%, roller compactors achieve 20-25%.

faqs.question: What is the difference between fill dirt and topsoil?
faqs.answer: Fill dirt is subsoil without organic matter, used for grading and foundations. Topsoil contains nutrients for plant growth and is used for landscaping.

faqs.question: How thick should fill lifts be?
faqs.answer: Compact fill in 6-8 inch loose lifts. Thicker lifts won't compact properly throughout and may settle later.

faqs.question: Do I need to test compaction?
faqs.answer: For structural applications (under foundations, driveways), compaction testing ensures fill meets engineering requirements - typically 95% standard Proctor.

faqs.question: How long before I can build on fill?
faqs.answer: Properly compacted engineered fill can be built on immediately. Uncompacted fill may take months to settle. Always verify with a geotechnical engineer for structures.

gravel.title: Gravel Calculator
gravel.description: Calculate gravel and aggregate quantities needed for driveways, paths, and landscaping projects.
gravel.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for length and width
gravel.length_tooltip: Length of the area to cover
gravel.width_tooltip: Width of the area to cover
gravel.formula: Volume = Area × Depth. Weight = Volume × Density. Tons = Weight ÷ 2000 (US) or ÷ 1000 (metric).
gravel.info_description: Gravel is sold by weight (tons) or volume (cubic yards). Different materials have different densities, affecting how much weight you need for a given area.

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_density: Density must be between 500 and 3000 kg/m³

howItWorks.title: How the Gravel Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Volume = Area × Depth; Weight = Volume × Density
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines both volume and weight of gravel needed based on coverage area, depth, and material type. Different gravel types have different densities.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter length and width of area to cover

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Specify desired gravel depth

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select gravel or aggregate type

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review volume in cubic yards/meters

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Check weight in tons for ordering

useCases.title: Driveway Construction
useCases.description: Calculate gravel base and surface layers for residential driveways.

useCases.title: Drainage Projects
useCases.description: Estimate gravel for French drains and drainage trenches.

useCases.title: Landscaping
useCases.description: Plan decorative gravel for paths, beds, and ground cover.

useCases.title: Base Preparation
useCases.description: Determine sub-base gravel quantities for pavers and concrete.

seoTips: Driveway gravel should be 4-6 inches deep for proper load bearing
Use angular crushed stone for driveways - it compacts better than round pea gravel
Layer gravel with larger stones at bottom, smaller on top for stability
Install landscape fabric under decorative gravel to prevent weed growth
Order by weight (tons) for bulk delivery, by bag for small projects

commonMistakes.solution: Use 4-6 inches for driveways, 2-3 inches for walkways
Crushed stone for driveways, pea gravel for drainage, river rock for decoration
Install edging to contain gravel and prevent spreading
Compact each layer for stable, long-lasting surfaces

faqs.question: How much does gravel cost per ton?
faqs.answer: Gravel costs $15-50 per ton for common types. Decorative stone ranges from $50-150 per ton. Delivery adds $50-100 depending on distance.

faqs.question: How many cubic yards per ton of gravel?
faqs.answer: Approximately 1.4 tons per cubic yard for most gravel. Lighter materials like lava rock are about 1 ton per cubic yard.

faqs.question: What size gravel is best for driveways?
faqs.answer: Use 3-4 inch base stone at bottom, 2 inch stone for middle layer, and 3/8 to 3/4 inch top stone that packs well.

faqs.question: How deep should gravel be for a patio base?
faqs.answer: Paver bases need 4-6 inches of compacted gravel sub-base plus 1 inch of bedding sand for proper drainage and stability.

faqs.question: Does gravel need to be compacted?
faqs.answer: Yes, especially for driveways and bases. Compact in 2-3 inch layers using a plate compactor or roller for best results.

sand.title: Sand Calculator
sand.description: Calculate sand volume and weight needed for construction projects.
sand.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for dimensions
sand.sand_type_tooltip: Different sand types have different densities affecting weight calculations
sand.length_tooltip: Length of the area to be filled with sand
sand.width_tooltip: Width of the area to be filled with sand
sand.depth_tooltip: Depth or thickness of the sand layer
sand.waste_factor_tooltip: Extra material for spillage and settling (typically 5-10%)
sand.formula: Volume = Length × Width × Depth. Weight = Volume × Density. Different sand types have different densities.
sand.info_description: Sand is essential for concrete, mortar, and landscaping. Different sand types have different densities, affecting the weight per volume.

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_waste: Waste factor must be between 0 and 100

howItWorks.title: How the Sand Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Volume = Length × Width × Depth; Weight = Volume × Density
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines both volume and weight of sand needed based on area dimensions and sand type. Different sand types have varying densities, affecting weight calculations.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter length, width, and depth of area to fill

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select sand type based on your application

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Add waste factor for spillage and settling

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review volume in cubic meters/yards

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Check weight for delivery and handling planning

useCases.title: Concrete Mixing
useCases.description: Calculate sand for concrete batching with proper proportions.

useCases.title: Paver Bedding
useCases.description: Estimate bedding sand for patio and driveway paver installation.

useCases.title: Pipe Bedding
useCases.description: Determine sand quantities for utility pipe installation bedding.

useCases.title: Playground Areas
useCases.description: Calculate sand fill for sandboxes and play areas.

seoTips: Wet sand weighs significantly more than dry sand - plan deliveries accordingly
Use sharp/coarse sand for concrete and mortar, fine sand for plastering
Paver bedding typically requires 1 inch depth of compacted sand
Order extra sand - it settles 10-15% when compacted
Store sand on plastic to prevent contamination from the ground

commonMistakes.solution: Use sharp sand for concrete, soft sand for mortar, and bedding sand for pavers
Add 10-15% extra for settling and compaction
Wet sand weighs 20-30% more - affects delivery vehicle capacity
Keep sand clean and covered to prevent debris and organic matter

faqs.question: How much does sand weigh per cubic meter?
faqs.answer: Dry loose sand weighs about 1,440 kg/m³ (1.44 tons). Wet sand weighs approximately 1,920 kg/m³ (1.92 tons). Density varies by type.

faqs.question: What type of sand should I use for concrete?
faqs.answer: Use sharp or coarse sand (concrete sand) for mixing concrete. The angular grains bond well with cement. Avoid beach sand which contains salt.

faqs.question: How much sand do I need under pavers?
faqs.answer: Paver bedding requires approximately 1 inch (25mm) of compacted sand. This equals about 0.3 cubic yards per 100 square feet.

faqs.question: What is the sand-to-cement ratio for mortar?
faqs.answer: Standard mortar uses a 1:4 to 1:6 cement to sand ratio by volume. Stronger mixes use 1:3 for load-bearing applications.

faqs.question: How many bags of sand equal a cubic yard?
faqs.answer: Approximately 54 bags (50 lb each) of sand equal one cubic yard. For a cubic meter, you need about 28-30 bags of 50kg sand.

asphalt.title: Asphalt Calculator
asphalt.description: Calculate asphalt quantity needed for paving driveways, parking lots, and roads.
asphalt.area_tooltip: Total surface area to be covered with asphalt
asphalt.thickness_tooltip: Depth of asphalt layer (typically 2-4 inches for driveways)
asphalt.density_tooltip: Weight of asphalt per cubic foot (default: 145 lbs/cu ft for hot mix)
asphalt.formula: Tons = Area × Thickness × Density / 2000. Standard hot mix asphalt density is 145 lbs/cu ft.
asphalt.info_description: Asphalt is typically ordered by the ton. This calculator estimates the weight of asphalt needed based on area, thickness, and material density.

errors.invalid_dimensions: Please enter valid area and thickness values
errors.positive_values: Area and thickness must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_density: Please enter a valid density value

howItWorks.title: How the Asphalt Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts your paving area and desired thickness into tons of asphalt needed. It uses standard hot mix asphalt density (145 lbs/cu ft) to provide accurate weight estimates for ordering.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the total area to be paved in square feet or meters

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Specify the desired asphalt thickness (2-4 inches for driveways)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Adjust the density if using a different asphalt mix type

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review the total tonnage required for your project

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Add 5-10% extra when ordering to account for variations

useCases.title: Residential Driveways
useCases.description: Calculate asphalt for home driveways with typical 2-3 inch thickness for standard vehicle traffic.

useCases.title: Commercial Parking Lots
useCases.description: Estimate materials for parking areas requiring 3-4 inch thickness for heavy use.

useCases.title: Driveway Resurfacing
useCases.description: Determine overlay quantities for existing asphalt repair with 1.5-2 inch thickness.

useCases.title: Private Roads and Paths
useCases.description: Plan asphalt needs for access roads and pathways on residential properties.

seoTips: Hot mix asphalt must be laid at 275-300°F for proper compaction
Asphalt compacts by approximately 25% during rolling - order accordingly
Proper drainage and sub-base preparation are essential for asphalt longevity
Apply sealcoat every 2-3 years to extend asphalt lifespan
Schedule paving for dry weather above 50°F (10°C) for best results

commonMistakes.solution: Install 4-6 inches of compacted gravel base for stable foundation
Use minimum 2 inches for light traffic, 3-4 inches for heavy vehicles
Ensure 1-2% slope for proper water runoff to prevent pooling
Asphalt cools quickly in cold conditions - pave when temperatures exceed 50°F

faqs.question: How many tons of asphalt do I need per square foot?
faqs.answer: For a 2-inch thickness, you need approximately 0.011 tons per square foot. For 3 inches, it's about 0.017 tons per square foot.

faqs.question: What is the cost of asphalt per ton?
faqs.answer: Hot mix asphalt typically costs $100-$200 per ton depending on location and market conditions. Delivery and installation add to the total cost.

faqs.question: How thick should a residential driveway be?
faqs.answer: Residential driveways should be 2-3 inches thick for cars and light trucks. Heavy vehicle areas need 3-4 inches.

faqs.question: How long does asphalt take to cure?
faqs.answer: Asphalt can be driven on within 24-48 hours but takes 6-12 months to fully cure. Avoid heavy loads and sharp turns during the first few months.

faqs.question: What is the difference between hot mix and cold mix asphalt?
faqs.answer: Hot mix is heated during production and provides a stronger, more durable surface for permanent installations. Cold mix is used for temporary repairs and patching.

landscaping.title: Landscaping Calculator
landscaping.description: Calculate mulch, soil, and sod quantities for garden and landscaping projects.
landscaping.area_tooltip: Total area for mulch and soil calculations
landscaping.mulch_depth_tooltip: Recommended: 2-4 inches for weed control and moisture retention
landscaping.soil_depth_tooltip: Depth of new soil layer to add
landscaping.sod_area_tooltip: Area to cover with sod/turf grass
landscaping.waste_factor_tooltip: Extra material for edges, curves, and waste (typically 5-10%)
landscaping.formula: Cubic Yards = Area (sq ft) × Depth (inches) / 324. Each material is calculated independently with waste factor applied.
landscaping.info_description: Accurate material estimates help avoid shortages and reduce waste. Mulch, soil, and sod are typically sold in different units - this calculator converts to standard measures.

errors.no_inputs: Please enter at least one material calculation (area with depth, or sod area)
errors.invalid_waste: Waste factor must be between 0 and 100

howItWorks.title: How the Landscaping Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines material quantities for mulch, soil, and sod by converting area and depth measurements into cubic yards or cubic meters. Each material is calculated independently with waste factor applied.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the project area in square feet or meters

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Specify mulch depth (2-4 inches recommended for weed control)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Add soil/topsoil depth if needed for bed preparation

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter sod area if installing new lawn

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Set waste factor and review material quantities

useCases.title: Garden Bed Renovation
useCases.description: Calculate mulch and soil amendments for flower beds and planting areas.

useCases.title: New Lawn Installation
useCases.description: Estimate sod rolls and topsoil needed for establishing fresh turf.

useCases.title: Tree and Shrub Mulching
useCases.description: Determine mulch quantities for proper tree ring coverage.

useCases.title: Complete Yard Makeover
useCases.description: Plan all materials for comprehensive landscaping projects.

seoTips: Apply 2-4 inches of mulch for optimal weed control and moisture retention
Keep mulch 3-4 inches away from tree trunks to prevent rot
Install sod within 24 hours of delivery for best results
Water new sod daily for the first two weeks to establish roots
Add 4-6 inches of topsoil for new garden beds with poor existing soil

commonMistakes.solution: Keep mulch 2-4 inches deep and away from plant stems
Till and amend soil, remove debris, and level before sod installation
Add 5-10% extra for curves, irregular shapes, and waste
Grade the area, add topsoil if needed, and ensure proper drainage

faqs.question: How much mulch do I need per square foot?
faqs.answer: For 3-inch depth, you need approximately 1 cubic yard per 108 square feet. A 2-inch depth covers about 162 square feet per cubic yard.

faqs.question: How long does mulch last?
faqs.answer: Organic mulch typically lasts 1-2 years before decomposing. Refresh annually by adding 1-2 inches to maintain proper depth.

faqs.question: How much topsoil do I need for a new lawn?
faqs.answer: For new lawns, apply 4-6 inches of quality topsoil. This equals approximately 0.5-0.75 cubic yards per 100 square feet.

faqs.question: When is the best time to install sod?
faqs.answer: Spring and fall are ideal for sod installation. Avoid extreme heat and ensure consistent watering during establishment.

faqs.question: What is the difference between mulch and compost?
faqs.answer: Mulch is placed on top of soil for weed control and moisture retention. Compost is mixed into soil to improve structure and add nutrients.

excavation-calculator.title: Excavation Calculator - Dirt & Soil Volume
excavation-calculator.description: Calculate excavation volume and dirt removal needed. Our free excavation calculator estimates cubic yards of soil to dig for foundations, pools, and trenches. Essential for site preparation and grading.

fill-dirt-calculator.title: Fill Dirt Calculator - Backfill Material
fill-dirt-calculator.description: Calculate fill dirt needed for backfilling and grading. Our free fill calculator estimates soil and topsoil quantities for leveling, raising ground, and landscape filling projects. Get accurate cubic yard estimates.

gravel-calculator.title: Gravel Calculator - Stone & Aggregate
gravel-calculator.description: Calculate gravel and crushed stone needed for driveways and paths. Our free gravel calculator estimates tons or cubic yards of aggregate required. Perfect for landscaping, base layers, and drainage projects.

sand-calculator.title: Sand Calculator - Construction Sand
sand-calculator.description: Calculate sand quantity needed for construction projects. Our free sand calculator estimates tons or cubic yards of sand required for concrete, mortar, landscaping, and base layers. Accurate material ordering.

asphalt-calculator.title: Asphalt Calculator - Paving Material
asphalt-calculator.description: Calculate asphalt quantity for driveways and roads. Our free asphalt calculator estimates tons of hot mix asphalt needed for paving projects. Perfect for parking lots, driveways, and road construction.

landscaping-calculator.title: Landscaping Calculator - Garden Materials
landscaping-calculator.description: Calculate landscaping materials for outdoor projects. Our free landscaping calculator estimates mulch, soil, sod, and plants needed. Perfect for garden design, yard renovation, and outdoor beautification.
